citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time inspection, Gem (a female cavapoo born 4/22/2022; Microchip ID: 900215006346088) was nursing 3 puppies
born on 5/23/2025 and was underweight. However, Gem was otherwise bright, alert, and active. Gem’s underweight
condition was evident based on her ribs being very prominent on palpation with a moderately concaved abdominal tuck.
Gem’s underweight condition was difficult to appreciate visually because she has a curly, fluffy hair coat. During the
inspection the licensee acknowledged the difficulty of maintaining Gem at optimal body weight. The licensee also stated
that he had not contacted the attending veterinarian to discuss Gem’s underweight condition. In a phone discussion with
the attending veterinarian, the attending veterinarian also acknowledge that the license had not communicated Gem’s
underweight condition to her.
An underweight body condition could be an indicator of a serious underlying medical condition. In addition, and
underweight nursing dog may not be able to provide her puppies the nutrition needed for them to thrive.
A program of veterinary care must be maintained that includes daily observation of all animals to assess their health and
well-being. In addition, there must be a mechanism of direct and accurate information, conveyed to the attending
veterinarian, on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being. Specifically, Gem’s conditions must be discussed
with and evaluated by the attending veterinarian.
To be corrected by close of business on 6/6/2025.

Tasha (a female cavapoo born on 12/27/2023) and a female dog (acquired from a relative) at the facility for breeding did
not have official identification. Official identification is essential for tracking of the transfer, sale, movement, and medical
diagnosis and treatment of dogs.
All dogs held on the premises, purchased, otherwise acquired, sold, otherwise disposed of, or removed from the premises
shall be identified with an official tag as described in 2.51 that has been affixed to the dogs neck by means of a collar or
shall be identified by a distinctive and legible tattoo approved by the administrator (which includes microchips).
To be correct by close of business on 6/6/2025

At the time of the inspection, one of the 10 adult dogs at the facility was not listed on the inventory (APHIS 7005 form).
The undocumented dog was a female brought to the facility by a relative for breeding. Records provide an important
source of information for the identification of each and every animal at the facility and can be important for tracing
animals.
The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose required information
[described in 2.75(a) (1)(i)-(ix)] concerning all dogs purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in
his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of.

At the time of the inspection, three primary enclosures housing dogs were not maintained to prevent injury to the dogs.
The outdoor portion these enclosures housing adult dogs (one of which also housed puppies) had large holes (3-6 inches
in diameter) hollowed out below the sheltered portion of the building. These conditions create opportunity for a dog or
puppy or an appendage to become entangled or entrapped, which could lead to injury, pain or distress.
The licensee must ensure that primary enclosures are maintained to protect dogs from injury. Specifically, holes that
could cause injury must be filled or repaired.

At the time of inspection, the exercise plan had not been approved by the attending veterinarian, as stated by the licensee
and the attending veterinarian. An exercise plan, approved by the attending veterinarian, is necessary to ensure that dogs
are provided with adequate space and opportunity for exercise for their health and well-being.
The licensee must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In
addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At the time of the inspection, used primary enclosures within the sheltered portion of the facility had not been sanitized as
often as necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt and debris. Within the used primary enclosures of the sheltered portion
of the facility there was an accumulation of dirt, stones, small sticks, and other debris. The dirt and debris was built up to a
depth of about ¼ inch in the corners and along the edges of the used primary enclosures.
Failure to clean and sanitize primary enclosures as often as necessary could expose the dogs to disease hazards.
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using
one of the methods prescribed in paragraph 3.11(b)(3), and more often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt,
debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards.
To be corrected by close of business on 6/6//2025

At the time of the inspection, the licensee had not implemented the written program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs
regarding the prescribed preventive treatment for blood parasites. The program of veterinary care, signed by the attending
veterinarian on 2/27/2025, required the monthly administration of Heartgard to the adult dogs. However, the licensee
stated that he had not administered Heartgard to any of the adult dogs, since the implementation of the most recent
program of veterinary care.
Failure to implement the preventative treatments prescribed in the program of veterinary care, by the attending
veterinarian, can lead to the development of diseases in the dogs that cause illness, discomfort, or death.
The licensee must follow the program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented, and signed by the
attending veterinarian. This includes administering the prescribed preventive treatments for contagious and deadly
diseases, parasites, and other pests (such as rabies, parvovirus, distemper, fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and
heartworm, etc.).
To be corrected by close of business on 6/27/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time inspection, Gem (a female cavapoo born 4/22/2022; Microchip ID: 900215006346088) was nursing 3 puppies 
born on 5/23/2025 and was underweight. However, Gem was otherwise bright, alert, and active. Gem’s underweight 
condition was evident based on her ribs being very prominent on palpation with a moderately concaved abdominal tuck. 
Gem’s underweight condition was difficult to appreciate visually because she has a curly, fluffy hair coat. During the 
inspection the licensee acknowledged the difficulty of maintaining Gem at optimal body weight. The licensee also stated 
that he had not contacted the attending veterinarian to discuss Gem’s underweight condition. In a phone discussion with 
the attending veterinarian, the attending veterinarian also acknowledge that the license had not communicated Gem’s 
underweight condition to her. 
 
An underweight body condition could be an indicator of a serious underlying medical condition. In addition, and 
underweight nursing dog may not be able to provide her puppies the nutrition needed for them to thrive. 
 
A program of veterinary care must be maintained that includes daily observation of all animals to assess their health and 
well-being. In addition, there must be a mechanism of direct and accurate information, conveyed to the attending 
veterinarian, on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being. Specifically, Gem’s conditions must be discussed 
with and evaluated by the attending veterinarian. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 6/6/2025. 
2.50(a) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Tasha (a female cavapoo born on 12/27/2023) and a female dog (acquired from a relative) at the facility for breeding did 
not have official identification. Official identification is essential for tracking of the transfer, sale, movement, and medical 
diagnosis and treatment of dogs. 
 
All dogs held on the premises, purchased, otherwise acquired, sold, otherwise disposed of, or removed from the premises 
shall be identified with an official tag as described in 2.51 that has been affixed to the dogs neck by means of a collar or 
shall be identified by a distinctive and legible tattoo approved by the administrator (which includes microchips).

To be correct by close of business on 6/6/2025 
2.75(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At the time of the inspection, one of the 10 adult dogs at the facility was not listed on the inventory (APHIS 7005 form). 
The undocumented dog was a female brought to the facility by a relative for breeding. Records provide an important 
source of information for the identification of each and every animal at the facility and can be important for tracing 
animals. 
 
The licensee shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose required information 
[described in 2.75(a) (1)(i)-(ix)] concerning all dogs purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in 
his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of. 
3.6(a)(2)(ii)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures. 
At the time of the inspection, three primary enclosures housing dogs were not maintained to prevent injury to the dogs. 
The outdoor portion these enclosures housing adult dogs (one of which also housed puppies) had large holes (3-6 inches 
in diameter) hollowed out below the sheltered portion of the building. These conditions create opportunity for a dog or 
puppy or an appendage to become entangled or entrapped, which could lead to injury, pain or distress. 
 
The licensee must ensure that primary enclosures are maintained to protect dogs from injury. Specifically, holes that 
could cause injury must be filled or repaired. 
3.8  Repeat
   
Exercise for dogs. 
At the time of inspection, the exercise plan had not been approved by the attending veterinarian, as stated by the licensee 
and the attending veterinarian. An exercise plan, approved by the attending veterinarian, is necessary to ensure that dogs 
are provided with adequate space and opportunity for exercise for their health and well-being. 
 
The licensee must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for exercise. In 
addition, the plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian. 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At the time of the inspection, used primary enclosures within the sheltered portion of the facility had not been sanitized as 
often as necessary to prevent accumulation of dirt and debris. Within the used primary enclosures of the sheltered portion 
of the facility there was an accumulation of dirt, stones, small sticks, and other debris. The dirt and debris was built up to a 
depth of about ¼ inch in the corners and along the edges of the used primary enclosures.

Failure to clean and sanitize primary enclosures as often as necessary could expose the dogs to disease hazards. 
 
Used primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks using 
one of the methods prescribed in paragraph 3.11(b)(3), and more often if necessary to prevent an accumulation of dirt, 
debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 6/6//2025 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
At the time of the inspection, the licensee had not implemented the written program of veterinary care (PVC) for dogs 
regarding the prescribed preventive treatment for blood parasites. The program of veterinary care, signed by the attending 
veterinarian on 2/27/2025, required the monthly administration of Heartgard to the adult dogs. However, the licensee 
stated that he had not administered Heartgard to any of the adult dogs, since the implementation of the most recent 
program of veterinary care. 
 
Failure to implement the preventative treatments prescribed in the program of veterinary care, by the attending 
veterinarian, can lead to the development of diseases in the dogs that cause illness, discomfort, or death. 
 
The licensee must follow the program of veterinary care for dogs that is developed, documented, and signed by the 
attending veterinarian. This includes administering the prescribed preventive treatments for contagious and deadly 
diseases, parasites, and other pests (such as rabies, parvovirus, distemper, fleas, worms, coccidia, giardia, and 
heartworm, etc.). 
 
To be corrected by close of business on 6/27/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
